reviewText:
Early Access Review

Welcome to your playground in the sky.

Volo Airsport is an extreme sports simulator/action game developed by Ramjet Anvil that is currently available through Steam Early Access. In Volo Airsport you take to the skies as a humble stick man sporting a wing-suit, whether you wish to go proximity flying right up against a ravine or wish to fly high above the world and take in the beautiful views you're gonna have fun with Volo. Despite being available to buy through Early Access for a few months now and being available even before that (DRM-Free) there's not a lot to do right now though from their website it's clear to see that Ramjet Anvil are working on some cool things which will only make the game better.

+Good graphics combined with a fair bit of graphical customisation
+A unique idea of flying around in wing-suits, obviously this has appeared in some games before but there's never been a full game based around it
+Great flight physics which feel realistic
+If you so wish you are able to have a predicted trajectory displayed on screen as well as aerodynamic forces (independent of each other) as well as the usual stuff like airspeed indicators and altitude displays
+Four different camera angles
+Very relaxing to play
+The map currently available is quite large but it's smaller than it looks due to there being extremely strong winds which stop you flying that way
+VR Support. Now this is something I usually wouldn't care about as I don't really like VR but Volo has actually made me want to get an Oculus just for the first person camera mode flying right up against the ravines
+Challenging time trial events
+Has a built in time trial course editor for you to make your own courses which can then be shared with other people
+Good controls (360 controller, unsure about Keyboard) which include some cool moves for your character, such as curling up into a ball
+The HUD can be disabled, allowing you to take some great screenshots of the game world
+Great soundtrack which adds to the relaxing feel of the game
+Friendly dev(s)

-Currently only one map
-As mentioned there's not too much to do right now
-Shadows are a tad glitchy in first person
-It's been a while since there was an update on progress or an actual, downloadable update for the game but it is a very small team with limited resources so it's to be expected

Here's a short gameplay clip I recorded:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=442135141

Verdict:
8

Volo Airsport, while lacking in content, is a fun and relaxing wing-suit game with good graphics, great physics and an interesting concept. If you're an Oculus owner or just someone who enjoys taking a relaxing flight through the skies in a game then this is not one to pass up on.

***This review was written using a key provided by the Developer of review purposes***

El K.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

***Review Update: 14th May ***

TL:DR  Neutral Rating, as of the release 3.6  - Their video shows you all you need know about Volo!

This is the first update I've ever experienced since buying this Early Access piece (Nov '15), so stick with me...

Firstly, as of this point, 20 out of 21 people found this review helpful.  Worth keeping in mind as it is rated as *Negative*.  I've kept my original review below as it is worth reading through the chain of comments that sparked off, due to my unhappiness, and the responses involved thereafter (10th Apr - 10th May).  To my surprise, the developers were not, as suspected by me, camped out in a bar, but are indeed still working on this project, perhaps with renewed vigour.  Who knows?

So, reviewing this again since I've had time to re-play and re-test.  It's definately more stable.  Actually, a lot more.  I regulary had to 'force quit' the previous version as it hung during loading about 50% of the time.  This one for me, had never failed to start since it came in and I've been in and out of it maybe 20 times so far.

As for the content change itself, I was hoping for something more significant than a few shacks and hated wind turbines dotted around as eye candy.  However, we are still promised parachutes and multiplayer.  No mention of more map choices as yet, but I'll be keeping an eye out for update news snippets for future possibilities of worthiness.  The sound output has also changed from being active, to passive.  I can't tell anymore just how close I was skimming past surfaces.  Something I loved.  Instead, now it sounds like a flag fluttering at 15mph no matter how close I get  to a virtual surface.  Oh, and there's dynamic grass now!  A nice touch for when you do eventually hit the deck at high speed, but Mehh"


Why have I rated this as Neutral?  Purely for the following reason.  I would recommend this
date: but for the lack of proof.  Proof of commitment and fervour.  One released update in 6 months dosen't do them justice.\n\nMy ultimate recommendation then
recommended: is to watch and wait.  Stick it on your wishlist
hoursPlayed: or follow it.  See for youself if it's worth bothering with in a few months time
voteText:
or set your own timescale as I can't even guestimate what will happen next with this project.  Perhaps take a chance and buy it if you've got the cash to spare.  To help them out and all that......


****Original Review Below****


Early Access..  Pahh..    ...Should read "Early Abandonment"

Don't bother with this.  After 6 months of complete silence from the (dare I use the word) devs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

We need a proximity flying game, glad to finally see this hit Steam.
Simple, beautiful, challenging.

If you are a fan of skydiving or proximity flying this is the game for you, its almost like you can feel and hear the power and force of the air gusts shoving you around.  Nothing beats ripping down a cliffside at 135mph and just one little mistake can be fatal.  The game's physics and mechanics are amazing, the controls are well done and playing with a controller is key.  You actually fly through simulated air pockets, lifts, and gusts while cruising at speeds of 100 to 160 + mph just feet above the ground...well that is the way I like to fly anyways.  The beauty of this game is the map is open, drop in from one of the various spawns some simulating base jumps others simulating jumping out of a helicopter.  Really well done little game how it stands right now, something new finally.

Its early access, meaning not much content small in size around 150mb.  Do not let that discourage you from buying this game, Volo Airsport has a lot of potential here.  Can't wait to see whats in store for the future.


A few things I hope to see in the future:

Replays
Different outfits, wingsuits"
Custom spawn points
Create your own custom runs placing rings where you want them
New maps
Ability to parachute at the end
Multiplayer "usually not a fan a MP games
date: but this one would be fun with other players"\nMap Editor"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is simply beautiful. I have always wanted to fly. Ever since I could recall, I looked up in the sky and wanted to be a bird - To fly. To truly fly. I wanted to soar between mountains, inside valleys, around cliffs and over forests.

Unfortunately, humans can't do that. But this game...

This game does that.

There is no story.

There is nothing but you, your wingsuit, the mountains and the air.

Simply beautiful in its purest of forms.

I hope they update the model, but... otherwise... simply, utterly beautiful in its simplicity and awesomeness.

If there is one game on all of steam... just one... this is it. This is the one you need to try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In this game you play as a man that is stuck in an endless loop of flight and death. Everytime he dies, he must fly again, only to blast into the ground at 180 kmph. He does some tricks on the way down, barrel rolls, backflips, enough to get the adrenaline flowing. I can only hope that the rush is enough to dull the pain.
All jokes aside however, this is definately the best proximity wingsuit flying game to date. Well optimized, handles great with a controller. I am truly exited to see how this game turns out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Key given by developer for reviewing purposes*

Volo Airsport is a gliding game where you glide around areas, and try to complete courses. For now there isn't a ton of stuff to do in the game but don't worry the game is still really entertaining. I do feel like the developers will grow this game into a much bigger game and make it even more fun than it is now.

Positives:
+Creative.
+Pretty original.
+Pretty graphics.
+Easy to learn.
+VR support.
+Fun.
+Lots of graphical options.
+Speed counter and a few other things.
+Relaxing.
+Course editor.
+You can play other people's courses.
+Wind.
+Good physics.

Negatives:
-Not a whole lot of stuff to do.
-Some graphical glitches here and there.
-Only 1 map.

Added Notes:

This game for now like I said does not have a ton of stuff to offer but if you are looking for a relaxing flying game then this is a game I recommend. I will also probably updates this review once the game has fully released.

Overall I rate this game a  7.5/10  pick this game up if you want to glide the skies and just relax for a few hours.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't write many reviews, but this game is special, so I ought to start...

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Overview: Volo Airsport is an amazing game that is currently under early development by the same people who brought you the Aurora Wager (a steampunk-style balloon race to get to the north pole). Volo is all about the freedom of flight in a wingsuit. It is different from other games because it has no real competition, leaderboards, or main goals (as of yet). There are no winners or losers, only people who learn to soar, and those who master the art of faceplanting.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Pros:
-Great developer
-Cheap price ($13 as of now)
-Tiny file size (almost 500mb, takes 3 minutes to download)
-Amazing graphics
-Oculus Rift and gamepad support
-Stunning physics and aerodynamics
-Wind and sound very clean and smooth
-Friendly developers (have had a chat with Ramjet Anvil and Frank V. more than once about Volo)
-Future plans to include parachutes and such
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Cons:
-Like all indie games, it is still under development and has multiple bugs
-Character model rather simple, just a blue human figure (red if you crash hard)
-No real goal or point (but that may be the idea of the game, just a stress reliever)
-Extremely simple, but controls are difficult (using keyboard)
-No instructions or tutorial, you are (literally) thrown off a cliff and told to fly
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Overall, if you are reading this, then you must be considering getting Volo. I have one word of advice:

Buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever since MS Flight Simulator 1, I've wanted a game that gave me the sensation of flying.  After all the years since, this game is it.  It's almost like the tagline for the first Christopher Reeve Superman movie: you will believe a man can fly.

I don't have VR gear, I crash all the time, there's no real goal, you can't land safely, it may never get finished - but I don't care.  I have so much fun gliding and taking in the scenery, I haven't regretted the $13 I paid for it (and you can get it for less elsewhere, including the developer's site.)  For the price of a movie ticket, I pick this up and play for however long and then put it down, to come back for more at other times.  It's relaxing and cathartic.  No software crashes, runs well, and its concept of physical flying works like a charm.

These devs deserve support for making a game that is different and already solid.  And I believe they will keep trying to finish it.  I urge anyone on the fence about purchasing to do it.  You'll know well within the Steam two hour return window whether it's right for you.  And I predict for most, they'll be pleasantly surprised.

For real fun, try the first person perspective.  Not for the easily queasy but a real trip trying to correct oneself without the avatar to watch.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you're into action packed games with big ♥♥♥♥ and fast cars, this game is not for you!  If you're into physics, gliding and a rip-roaring good time, let me introduce you to Volo Airsport!  Fun, fast, frantic, and fun!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you're in to wingsuit/proximity flying but don't have the time/budget/cahones to do it IRL, this might be the next best option. Landscape is beautiful. Adding a parachute would be great, but attempting to land without breaking bones is a fun challenge. I imagine Volo + Oculus would be great. For a relatively inexpensive early access game, it's great to sink some time in to.

Early Access Review

“At one point last night, while chasing contours on the new Alpine map, I actually found myself wiping a tear from my eye.”  This feeling is so true (with good music in background).
I bought a XBox360 joystick for this game. And this true, the experience is so much different with it.
The sensation is so insane.
Some bugs to fix (game crashes).
I hope there will be other mountains in the future (with snow etc...)
AND more games configurations to be more playable on little computers. (Distance of view ? less Mesh ? multicore using ? avoid air/steam effects ?)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you ever dream of flying a wingsuit, this is the perfect game for you. There are still a few things missing, like proper models and parachutes, but gameplay wise the game feels nearly finished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to be honest, the concept is great and the mechanics feel good. But the state the game is currently in does not satisfy me. There is no way I can succesfully finish a flight, because no matter how well you've flown, you will always end up crashing into the ground because there are no parachutes in game yet. There is basically no ending, which makes the game feel like we're just testing the flight mechanics - and that's it.

I understand this release is an early access release, so I shouldn't expect to see a finished game. I'm just commenting on the current state of the game.

Other than that, Volo is looking promising, so we'll see what happens!

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI've played some single player flying games before, as well as JC3(although the wingsuiting in that is a little weird IMO) but this game take wingsuiting over the top. The game isn't even finished yet, and I've already put in some hours. The community is super friendly, which is hard to find these days, th devs are always active on the forums, and overall the game is really fun. You can cruise at high altitudes if you would like, or you can go 2 meters of the ground and do barrel rolls of a cliff and a back as well as a front flip as well. The game is super fun to play and overall this game is Way Too good to be an early access game. The progress is a little slow on the game, but that you can expect with a small developer team, and the next thing on their list is parachutes and multiplayer. Think about it. The game is fun WITHOUT PARACHUTES AND MULTIPLAYER. That goes miles to tell you how good this game is. I would Highly recommend you pick up this game, whether to back up the idea or to play the game for long periods of time without stopping. PICK THIS GAME UP.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There is so much potential to that game. It currently is a shell of a game, as early access games are supposed to be, but the core of the experience is satisfying and fun.
The general ambiance and core physics are incredibly cool to play with, and I suspect will be the main draw for a while.

[EARLY ACCESS NOTES]
There is only one mountain in the game, and time trials are in, but that is pretty much it. The soundtrack is absent from what I can tell, so play something with it. Someone on the discussion suggested boards of Canada, it works really well.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is the only Rift supported game available so far that I enjoy casually jumping into every night. The physics are very good, the play is relaxing and easy to reset and do again. Even without being fully fleshed out I can already see the potential. Worth it for a good zen experience that doesn't get old.

I purchased Volo Airsport when i received my oculus rift cv1 and thoroughly enjoying the game
Even on the oculus rift the gameplay is varied and thrilling. Graphics are superb, sound is good and there are many tracks to play on
I find the game challenging and extremely fun.
If you have an oculus rift cv1 and have your VR legs go get it and enjoy the ride! (start off in 3rd person though until you get used to it)
